newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Sabena reopens Moscow, Palma routes. [CORRECTED 14:38 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Sabena reopens Moscow, Palma routes. [CORRECTED 14:38 GMT]

text.p: Belgian national airline Sabena SA said on Thursday it would reopen its direct routes to Moscow and Palma de Mallorca from April 1.
"The economic development of (Moscow) in the past few years has fanned demand for this destination," it said in a statement.
The daily flight to Moscow was part of its plans to raise the number of European destinations to 70 from 60 and reinforce its hub-and-spoke network.
It would add additional daily flights to Prague and Budapest (corrects name of destination from Bucharest) from March 30.
The loss-making carrier, owned 49.5 percent by Swissair, said it would fly three times a week to Palma, one of Spain's top tourist spots.
It stopped flying to Palma in 1972-1973. Direct flights to Moscow were suspended in the 1960s, but flights were resumed, via Warsaw, in the 1980s.
Sabena added its cooperation with Virgin Express on short-haul destinations to London-Heathrow and Barcelona had allowed it to open up new routes.
